citation.article-title: Marmoricola aurantiacus gen. nov., sp. nov., a coccoid member of the family Nocardioidaceae isolated from a marble statue
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Marmoricola. (Mar.mo.ri'co.la. L. neutr. n. marmor marble; L. masc. suffix -cola inhabitant of; Marmoricola inhabitant of marble)
Cells are Gram-positive, not acid-fast, spherical, occurring singly, in pairs, tetrads and small clusters.
Colonies are circular, convex, entire, orange-pigmented, shiny and smooth.
They can become rough and shaped like craters in old cultures.
The cell wall peptidoglycan contains LL-A2pm as characteristic diamino acid and a single glycine residue as interpeptide bridge (type A3γ).
Phospholipids are phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglycerol.
The cellular fatty acid profile consists of straight-chain saturated and monounsaturated components and TBSA as the only branched chain fatty acid.
The DNA G+C content is 72 mol%.
Phylogenetically, this genus is a member of the family Nocardioidaceae (Stackebrandt et al., 1997).
The type species is Marmoricola aurantiacus.
